Algorithm Analysis â€¢ Analyse the time and space efficiency of an algorithm, without reference to specific implementation details (language, hardware, RAM size etc) â€œAlgorithm analysis is a way to compare the time and space efficiency of programs with respect to their possible inputs, but irrespective of other context.â€* *https://bradfieldcs.com/algos/analysis/introduction/ Emprical vs Analytical Approach â€¢ What we just did with the three versions of summing up numbers was an empirical approach. â€¢ We ran experiments with real code, and measured the actual time/space taken. â€¢ What is more useful is a more abstract, analytical approach. â€¢ Uses a high-level description of the algorithm instead of a specific implementation â€¢ Characterizes running time (and space) as a function of the input size (ğ’) â€¢ How does my running time ğ‘‡ ğ‘› change, as I increase my input size ğ‘› ? Empirical studies vs Theoretical analysis Empirical studies â€¢ It is necessary to implement the algorithm, which may be difficult â€¢ Results may not be indicative of the running time on other inputs not included in the experiment â€¢ In order to compare two algorithms, the same hardware and software environments must be used â€¢ Results may be more accurate, realistic, and relevant to the specific context. Theoretical analysis â€¢ Uses a high-level description of the algorithm instead of an implementation â€¢ Characterizes running time as a function of the input size (ğ‘›) â€¢ Considers all possible inputs â€¢ Allows us to evaluate the speed of an algorithm independently of the hardware/software environment â€¢ Results will be indicative.
